results_summary: The study found that betel nut chewing led to acute esophageal hematoma in a patient, presenting with chest pain and hematemesis. Treatment with fasting, gastric acid inhibition, and blood volume maintenance resulted in gradual absorption of the hematoma after one week.
population_specificity: 72-year-old female with acute symptoms after chewing betel nut.
interactions: Aspirin use was noted as a potential risk factor for esophageal hematoma in betel nut chewers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bit chewing (a form of sham feeding) reduces gastric emptying time, small intestinal transit time, and total orocecal transit time in healthy horses.
results_summary: Bit chewing significantly decreased total orocecal transit time (OCTT) compared to control conditions, though reductions in gastric emptying time (GET) and small intestinal transit time (SITT) were not statistically significant. The study suggests bit chewing may be a safe and inexpensive intervention for ileus in horses.
population_specificity: Nine healthy horses
effective_dosage: Bit chewing for 20 minutes every 6 hours
study_duration: Each condition (experimental or control) lasted until all video capsules were retrieved or up to 30 days, with a 3-week washout period between conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between chewing performance and dietary intakes in children with Cerebral Palsy (CP).
results_summary: Chewing function was impaired in 70% of children, with a negative correlation between chewing performance (KCPS scores) and daily protein intake, and positive correlations between liquid-blenderized food intake and KCPS scores. The study found that decreased chewing performance was associated with lower protein intake and higher reliance on liquid-blenderized foods.
population_specificity: Forty children with CP aged 2-6 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the parasitic wasp Cotesia congregata suppresses feeding in its host, the caterpillar Manduca sexta, by examining feeding behavior and neurophysiology.
results_summary: Parasitized caterpillars showed reduced feeding and altered chewing muscle activity, similar to non-parasitized caterpillars during illness or molting. Severing neural connections re-activated chewing, suggesting suppression by external inputs rather than damage to chewing mechanisms.
population_specificity: Caterpillars (Manduca sexta) parasitized by the wasp Cotesia congregata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the cytotoxicity, proliferative, and microbiological activities of lysozyme hydrochloride and ascorbic acid in medicated chewing gum for dental applications.
results_summary: The combination of lysozyme hydrochloride and ascorbic acid stimulated cell proliferation without toxicity, increased antioxidant protection, and inhibited biofilm formation in oral microorganisms, including Streptococcus mutans and Candida albicans.
population_specificity: Preclinical study using human hepatocarcinoma cells (HepG2), human embryonic kidney cells (Hek293), and mouse aortic endothelial cells (MAEC), as well as microbial strains (Streptococcus mutans, Staphylococcus aureus, etc.).
effective_dosage: 20 mg ascorbic acid and 10 mg lysozyme hydrochloride per 1 gum.

study_goal: To investigate the effect and clinical value of magnetic attachments in oral restoration compared to routine oral restoration.
results_summary: The research group using magnetic attachments showed higher total effective rate, lower adverse reactions, improved masticatory efficiency, fixation force, comfort, aesthetic outcomes, and better periodontal rehabilitation compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 72 cases of dental defects treated at Haishu District Stomatological Hospital.
study_duration: Follow-up conducted over one year with assessments at 6-month intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether restorative treatment of worn dentition impacts masticatory performance parameters.
results_summary: Restorative treatment improved self-reported chewing ability but had no effect on objective masticatory performance tests. Insufficient evidence exists to confirm the therapeutic role of such treatments for tooth wear.
population_specificity: Patients with worn dentition (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of postoperative gum chewing on gastrointestinal function recovery in women undergoing laparoscopic gynecological surgery for benign conditions.
results_summary: Postoperative gum chewing significantly reduced the time to first bowel sounds and first passage of flatus but did not significantly affect time to first defecation, patient mobilization, hospital stay, or bowel obstruction risk. Subgroup analysis showed no significant benefit for laparoscopic hysterectomies.
population_specificity: Women undergoing laparoscopic gynecological surgery for benign indications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the fracture resistance of contracted endodontic cavities (CECs) versus traditional endodontic cavities (TECs) in mandibular molars after simulated chewing.
results_summary: The CEC group showed higher fracture resistance than the TEC group, but the difference was not statistically significant. The control group (intact teeth) had significantly higher fracture resistance than both experimental groups.
population_specificity: Extracted human mandibular molars with intact crowns and mature root apices, free of caries, attrition, restorations, and cracks.
study_duration: Simulated 1 year of clinical function (240,000 masticatory cycles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chewing function tests as assessment tools for identifying potential dental treatment needs.
results_summary: The study found that chewing function tests are effective for assessing dental treatment needs but are not a substitute for routine dental examinations. They can help laypersons determine if a dental consultation is necessary.
population_specificity: Individuals dependent on care, particularly those with increasing life expectancy and demographic changes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if gum chewing improves salivary flow rates and subjective relief from xerostomia in elderly and medically compromised individuals.
results_summary: The meta-analysis confirmed a significant increase in unstimulated salivary flow rate with gum chewing compared to control, though self-reported xerostomia improvements were inconsistent across studies. Longer chewing durations enhanced salivation rates.
population_specificity: Elderly (>60 years) and medically compromised individuals with xerostomia.
effective_dosage: Daily chewing of gum for two weeks or longer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if menthol gum chewing reduces nausea, vomiting, and hospital stay duration in children after appendectomy.
results_summary: Menthol gum chewing significantly lowered nausea scores and reduced hospital stay by one day compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-18 years who underwent appendectomy.
effective_dosage: Chewing gum for an average of 15 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to better understand hyolingual morphology, biomechanics, and neural control in humans and animal models to improve treatments for dysphagia.
results_summary: The study revealed significant variation in hyoid chain and suprahyoid muscle morphology among animal models, similar tongue movements during chewing between animals and humans, and falsified traditional hypotheses of tongue base retraction during swallowing. Neural activity in orofacial primary motor cortex strongly encodes tongue kinematics in macaques, suggesting potential for brain-machine interfaces to assist lingual function recovery.
population_specificity: Animal models (e.g., macaques) and humans (indirectly referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess behavioral and psychosocial risk factors that lead individuals to initiate and/or maintain betel quid (BQ) chewing in developed and developing countries.
results_summary: The study found that dependent BQ chewers struggled to quit due to habituation, addiction, and withdrawal symptoms, while social chewers in Southeast Asia resisted quitting due to cultural and peer influences. Behavioral and psychosocial factors were identified as major barriers to cessation.
population_specificity: Individuals in developed and developing countries, with a focus on Southeast Asian populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the CAMCAM program could improve attitudes and behaviors related to oral health, mastication, and diet, as well as reduce oral frailty in older adults.
results_summary: The CAMCAM program significantly improved oral and systemic frailty (measured by OFI-8 and KCL scores) in the Oral Frailty group and enhanced awareness of chewing in the Robust group. The program showed potential as a community-based intervention for frailty prevention.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults in Japan (mean age 72.3 ± 5.7 years, 58.7% women).
effective_dosage: Monthly sessions with a "munchy" textured lunch (specific nutritional details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a predictive model for oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) in a population with low HPV prevalence and frequent betel nut chewing.
results_summary: Betel nut chewing was negatively associated with p16-positive OPC and significantly associated with poorer overall survival in the study population. High-risk groups included those with cT4 stage or high EGFR expression.
population_specificity: 116 patients with OPC, predominantly male (88.8%), from a referral cancer center in an area with low HPV prevalence and frequent betel nut chewing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the fracture resistance of CAD/CAM monolithic zirconia crowns supported by titanium and Ti-base abutments after chewing simulation and thermocyclic aging.
results_summary: The study found that both titanium and Ti-base abutments supported zirconia crowns with high fracture resistance, showing no statistically significant differences between groups, even after chewing simulation and thermocyclic aging. Survival rates were 100% for both groups subjected to these conditions.
population_specificity: Mandibular first molar CAD/CAM monolithic zirconia crowns (in vitro study).
study_duration: Chewing simulation (1.2 × 10^6 cycles × 50 N load, 1.4 Hz) and thermocyclic aging (3,911 cycles/5°C to 55°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal chewing during gestation could mitigate hippocampal microglia-mediated neuroinflammation and cognitive impairments induced by prenatal stress in offspring.
results_summary: Maternal chewing significantly reduced serum corticosterone levels, suppressed microglial overactivation, and normalized inflammatory cytokine levels in offspring exposed to prenatal stress, both under basal conditions and after LPS administration.
population_specificity: Pregnant mice and their male offspring.
effective_dosage: Not specified (wooden stick provided during stress periods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of habitual khat chewing on blood pressure, body mass index, and physiological aspects of sexuality among residents of an Ethiopian town.
results_summary: The study found that khat chewing had significant adverse effects on health, with 81.2% of participants reporting adverse effects, particularly among those who co-used tobacco, coffee, or tea. Adverse effects included physical problems, abuse potential, and social effects.
population_specificity: Residents of Hosanna, Southern Ethiopia, primarily male (80%), with a mean age of 28.7±5.7 years.
interactions: Co-use with tobacco, coffee, or tea increased adverse effects (adjusted odds ratio = 4.8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low concentrations of tannin extract from Acacia mearnsii bark on chewing behavior, ruminal fermentation, and nitrogen partitioning in dairy cows.
results_summary: The tannin extract did not affect rumination behavior but increased meal size and duration of the first daily meal while reducing meal frequency. Cows fed the highest tannin concentration (0.43% of diet DM) selectively avoided larger feed particles in the morning.
population_specificity: Twenty Holstein dairy cows (590 ± 89 kg body weight, 78 ± 33 days in lactation).
effective_dosage: 0, 0.14, 0.29, or 0.43% of diet dry matter basis.
study_duration: 21-day treatment periods with a 14-day adaptation period (total 35 days per treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of nicotine gum versus nicotine patches in aiding smoking cessation, using salivary cotinine levels as a biochemical measure.
results_summary: Nicotine patches showed higher quit rates and better compliance than nicotine gum, with significantly greater reductions in salivary cotinine levels. The patch group also demonstrated better adherence and efficacy over the 12-week period.
population_specificity: 72 known smokers willing to undergo nicotine replacement therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the coordination of masticatory muscles during chewing at different speeds to understand motor control strategies.
results_summary: The study found that two main muscle synergies explained over 98% of muscle activity variation during chewing, with consistent patterns across different speeds and participants, supporting the use of similar motor control strategies.
population_specificity: Ten healthy individuals.
effective_dosage: Not specified (chewing gum at different speeds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of prosthetic rehabilitation methods (conventional complete dentures, single median implant-retained overdentures, and two-implant-retained overdentures) in improving chewing and other outcomes for edentulous patients.
results_summary: Both single median implant-retained overdentures (SIMOD) and two-implant-retained overdentures (TIMOD) significantly improved chewing, patient comfort, and oral health-related quality of life compared to conventional complete dentures (CD). The improvements were statistically significant at 3, 6 months, and 1 year.
population_specificity: Thirty completely edentulous patients (15 in each intervention group) presenting to the Faculty of Dental Sciences, University of Peradeniya.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction between two implant-retained maxillary overdenture attachment systems (telescopic vs. ball-and-socket) in terms of comfort, chewing, handling, and overall satisfaction.
results_summary: The telescopic attachment group showed significant improvement in comfort, chewing, handling, and overall satisfaction after 3 months, while the ball-and-socket group only improved in appearance. The telescopic attachment outperformed the ball-and-socket in most satisfaction parameters.
population_specificity: 18 completely edentulous maxillary ridge patients aged 45-60 years (mean age: 53).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of gene-based therapies on swallowing dysfunction, including chewing, in individuals with Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA).
results_summary: Pre-therapy studies identified significant chewing and swallowing dysfunction in SMA patients, while post-gene therapy studies suggested potential improvements or stabilization in these functions, with a shift toward more objective assessment methods like VFSS.
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA), particularly those with severe phenotypes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of submucosal dexamethasone (DEX) on postoperative pain, swelling, chewing efficiency, trismus, healing, and discomfort after periodontal flap surgery (PFS).
results_summary: The study found that submucosal DEX reduced pain, swelling, and trismus compared to the control group, with improved chewing efficiency on the first day. However, healing, discomfort, and analgesic consumption were similar between groups.
population_specificity: 25 patients undergoing periodontal flap surgery in the mandible.
effective_dosage: 8 mg (2 mL) dexamethasone injected submucosally postoperatively.
study_duration: Evaluations were conducted up to 7 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dual-wavelength PBMT (red and infrared) versus infrared laser PBMT alone on tissue healing after third molar extraction, including impacts on chewing difficulty.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between the two PBMT protocols in bone or soft tissue healing, pain, bleeding, edema, or chewing difficulty after third molar extraction. Both treatments yielded similar postoperative clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: 20 adult patients (mean age 28.58 ± 8.94 years, 60% female) with all four third molars extracted.
effective_dosage: Not specified (PBMT protocols: 808 nm IRL alone vs. 660 + 808 nm dual-wavelength).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the pharmacodynamic equivalence of orally administered oxylanthanum carbonate (swallowed) to lanthanum carbonate (chewed) in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that oxylanthanum carbonate was bioequivalent to lanthanum carbonate in reducing urinary phosphate excretion, with similar efficacy and tolerability. Both treatments were well tolerated with equal incidence of adverse events.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how early-life exposure to different food sensory properties, including chewing, shapes eating behaviors and food preferences in infants and toddlers.
results_summary: The study highlights that early exposure to varied food textures and oral processing skills during weaning is crucial for developing eating behaviors, which persist into later childhood. It also notes challenges in specific child populations, such as those with developmental issues or tube-fed infants.
population_specificity: Infants and toddlers, including healthy populations and clinical groups (e.g., tube-fed children or those with developmental challenges).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of chewing gum in reducing pain intensity in patients undergoing orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: Chewing gum significantly reduced pain intensity compared to pharmacologic agents and placebo, with similar pain reduction levels as bite wafers. The meta-analysis included 16 RCTs and showed statistically significant results.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.
study_duration: Pain assessed 24 hours after initial archwire placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early feeding or chewing gum postoperatively could improve gastrointestinal function recovery and comfort in women undergoing repeat cesarean sections.
results_summary: Both early feeding and chewing gum significantly improved postoperative gastrointestinal function recovery and comfort compared to the control group, with no significant difference between the two experimental groups.
population_specificity: Women undergoing repeat cesarean sections (n=103).
effective_dosage: Chewing gum postoperatively, followed by a clear fluid diet after 2 hours, a pureed diet after 6 hours, and a regular soft diet after passing flatus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of the OHS-interRAI tool versus the current section in identifying oral health problems, including chewing function, among nursing home residents.
results_summary: The OHS-interRAI detected a higher proportion of chewing function problems (13.7%) compared to the current section (6.8%), suggesting improved identification of oral health issues. No significant difference was found in discomfort or pain related to chewing.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65 years or older in Flemish and Dutch nursing homes.
study_duration: Assessments with the current section spanned from October 2016 to January 2023, and with the OHS-interRAI from October 2020 to January 2023.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare chewing patterns in children with unilateral Molar Incisor Hypomineralization (MIH) to those without MIH and assess how MIH severity influences chewing deviation risk.
results_summary: Children with unilateral severe MIH were 3.57 times more likely to exhibit chewing deviation than those without MIH, and chewing deviation prevalence was higher in severe MIH cases (52%) compared to controls (24%). The study rejected the null hypothesis, confirming that unilateral MIH affects masticatory patterns.
population_specificity: 121 children (45 with mild MIH, 42 with severe MIH, and 34 controls with unilateral chewing complaints but no MIH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the costs, treatment time, and general health-related quality of life between digitally designed (3D-IOD) and conventionally fabricated (C-IOD) implant-supported overdentures for edentulous patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in general health-related quality of life between the two types of overdentures. However, the digital approach (3D-IOD) showed a 14.2% reduction in initial costs, 41.1% shorter treatment time, and 47.1% fewer treatment sessions compared to conventional methods.
population_specificity: 36 fully edentulous patients with six maxillary and two mandibular implants.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (dental intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Each overdenture type was worn for 1 year (total study duration: 2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for postoperative ileus and evaluate interventions, including chewing gum, to manage or prevent it.
results_summary: Chewing gum was identified as an effective intervention to shorten or prevent postoperative ileus, alongside other methods like minimally invasive surgery and early enteral nutrition. These interventions are integrated into current guidelines for enhanced recovery after surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing abdominal tumor surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of occlusal splints (OS) and botulinum toxin-A (BTX-A) in reducing jaw muscle pain and improving functional outcomes in patients with probable sleep bruxism.
results_summary: Both OS and BTX-A effectively reduced jaw muscle pain and improved oral health-related quality of life, with OS showing slight advantages in specific functional parameters. BTX-A was associated with mild discomfort during chewing in some participants.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) with probable sleep bruxism and jaw muscle pain.
study_duration: 6 months (with assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and initial efficacy of KSL-W formulated into chewing gum for reducing plaque and gingival inflammation while minimizing disruption to the oral microbiome.
results_summary: KSL-W demonstrated safety with no severe adverse events and showed efficacy in reducing plaque and gingival inflammation, particularly at doses ≥20 mg, with the 30 mg dose appearing optimal.
population_specificity: Gingivitis population
effective_dosage: Single doses (2-100 mg) in Phase 1; multiple doses (4-75 mg) in Phase 2a

study_goal: To compare the fracture resistance of anterior teeth restored with glass fiber post and conventional lithium disilicate crowns versus endocrowns made of lithium disilicate or hybrid ceramics.
results_summary: LDS endocrowns showed fracture resistance similar to GFP-supported full coverage LDS crowns, with more restorable fractures. Vita-Enamic endocrowns had lower fracture resistance than other groups but still higher than physiologic load, with more restorable fractures than LDS endocrowns and GFP LDS crowns.
population_specificity: Central incisors with 2-mm ferrule and 1-mm shoulder finish line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare functional impairments, discomfort, and satisfaction among patients treated with different types of orthodontic appliances (lingual, labial, or mixed) regarding chewing and other aspects.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in chewing difficulty among the three appliance groups, indicating similar efficacy in this aspect. Lingual and labial appliances caused similar overall pain levels, but with different localized pain patterns.
population_specificity: Patients within one year of the end of orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of electroacupuncture on sensitivity and orofacial function, including chewing, in patients undergoing orthognathic surgery.
results_summary: The study assessed chewing function using the Chewing Quality Assessment Questionnaire, with evaluations repeated at three and six months post-treatment initiation, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bimaxillary orthognathic surgery and genioplasty.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of electroacupuncture per session, frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an evaluation period is necessary for clinical and patient success when increasing occlusal vertical dimension (OVD) for full mouth rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found no strong evidence that an evaluation period improves clinical or patient-reported outcomes when increasing OVD. Removable devices caused chewing difficulties and esthetic discomfort, while fixed restorations were more effective for managing patient expectations.
population_specificity: Dentate adults requiring an increase in occlusal vertical dimension (OVD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether gingivitis exacerbates inflammatory responses and subclinical atherosclerotic markers in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), potentially affecting chewing function due to periodontal disease.
results_summary: The study found that PCOS patients with gingivitis exhibited increased neutrophil hyperactivity, promoting endothelial interaction, which may contribute to atherosclerotic disease. Periodontal parameters like bleeding on probing, plaque, and calculus indices were higher in PCOS patients with gingivitis, potentially impairing chewing function.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), including subgroups with and without gingivitis, and a control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to introduce and define the concept of oral frailty, including its assessment using the OF-5 checklist, and to promote awareness and collaboration among healthcare providers.
results_summary: The study found that oral frailty, characterized by slight declines in oral function such as difficulty chewing, affects approximately 40% of community-dwelling older adults and is associated with poor dietary variety, social isolation, physical frailty, disability, and mortality. The OF-5 checklist was introduced as a tool to assess oral frailty without requiring a dental health professional.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single midline implant in the edentulous mandible improves dietary habits and chewing efficiency, comparing immediate vs. delayed loading protocols.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in nutritional intake frequency but noted a significant decrease in avoidance of coarse/hard-textured foods after 60 months, with earlier improvements in the immediate-loading group.
population_specificity: Edentulous patients with existing complete dentures in both jaws.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate strategies for improving ticagrelor/prasugrel use in the acute phase of STEMI, including crushed or chewed administration.
results_summary: The study found that chewing ticagrelor/prasugrel tablets can provide faster platelet inhibition when oral administration is compromised, though increased loading doses or earlier administration did not significantly close the platelet inhibition gap.
population_specificity: Patients with STEMI undergoing PCI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical characteristics and variability in symptoms, including chewing difficulties, among patients with myasthenia gravis (MG) classified by the MGFA system.
results_summary: The study found that bulbar symptoms, including difficulty chewing, were present even in mild MGFA class I patients (1.1-1.9% mild, 0.3-1.1% moderate) and more prevalent in class II patients (8.5-16.4% mild, 4.7-7.4% moderate, 0.3-0.9% severe). However, symptom severity varied widely within each MGFA class.
population_specificity: Patients with myasthenia gravis (n=1232) from the United States, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the role of the temporomandibular joint in functions like chewing and to outline common disorders and diagnostic approaches related to temporomandibular joint dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that temporomandibular joint dysfunction affects about 30% of the population, with higher prevalence in young to middle-aged women, but only 5%-10% of symptomatic cases require treatment. Common disorders include myofascial syndrome and articular disorders, while imaging is necessary for non-responsive cases or diagnostic uncertainty.
population_specificity: General population, with higher prevalence in young to middle-aged women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss how molar incisor hypomineralisation (MIH) affects oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) in children, including impacts on chewing and other daily activities.
results_summary: The study found that children with severe MIH may struggle with chewing, among other daily activities, due to dental hypersensitivity, posteruptive breakdown, and aesthetic concerns. MIH negatively impacts OHRQoL, affecting functional, social, and emotional aspects of life.
population_specificity: Children with molar incisor hypomineralisation (MIH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pain-reducing efficacy of chewing gum against pharmaceutical (ibuprofen) and another non-pharmaceutical (photobiomodulation) intervention in orthodontic patients after elastomeric separator placement.
results_summary: Chewing gum showed comparable pain reduction to ibuprofen, though the difference among all three groups was not statistically significant. Patients experienced lower pain levels in the gum and ibuprofen groups, with peak pain occurring at 12 and 24 hours post-separator placement.
population_specificity: 90 orthodontic patients (equal males and females).
effective_dosage: Chewing sugar-free gum for 5 minutes every 8 hours as needed for pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Arecae Semen Compounds (ASC) in treating depression, focusing on its antidepressant ability and potential carcinogenic risks.
results_summary: ASC lowered HAMD scores, alleviated depression-related symptoms, and showed a lower incidence of adverse events, suggesting it may be an effective and safe complementary therapy for depression, though the evidence remains uncertain.
population_specificity: 787 patients with depression across nine randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between oral leukoplakia recurrence and surgical techniques, as well as clinicopathological factors, including risk habits like betel quid chewing.
results_summary: The study found that betel quid chewing was significantly associated with higher oral leukoplakia recurrence, and recurrent oral leukoplakia had a 7.39 times higher risk of malignant transformation than nonrecurrent cases.
population_specificity: Patients with oral leukoplakia undergoing surgical treatment (7,614 samples across 80 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare orofacial myofunctional characteristics, masticatory performance, and facial thermal profiles in individuals with Parkinson’s disease (PD) and spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA3) versus healthy controls.
results_summary: The study found that PD and SCA3 patients showed differences in orofacial mobility, swallowing, and masticatory function compared to healthy controls, along with greater facial temperature asymmetries and longer eating times. However, masticatory performance measured by chewing gum did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: 72 participants aged 30-85 years, divided into PD, SCA3, and healthy control groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of gum chewing training on occlusal force, masseter muscle thickness, and mandibular shape in healthy adults.
results_summary: Gum chewing training significantly increased maximum occlusal force and occlusal contact area after 3 months but had no significant effect on masseter muscle thickness or mandibular shape.
population_specificity: Healthy adults
effective_dosage: Chewing gum three times a day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of nutritional strategies, including nutraceuticals, on chronic craniofacial pain associated with temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to assess the efficacy of nutraceuticals for TMDs, though preclinical and limited clinical data suggest potential therapeutic benefits. Further research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic craniofacial pain due to TMDs, including preclinical models (mostly craniofacial inflammatory rodents).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a myofunctional intervention program, including electromyographic biofeedback, in attenuating facial aging signs and improving orofacial functions like chewing, swallowing, and smiling.
results_summary: The intervention reduced facial aging signs, particularly in the therapy group (TG), and improved chewing and swallowing functions in both groups. Electromyographic biofeedback increased participant satisfaction, but aesthetic gains were partially lost after an eight-week washout period.
population_specificity: 30 women aged 50-60 years.
effective_dosage: 50-minute sessions weekly for nine weeks, then monthly for six months.
study_duration: Nine weeks of weekly sessions, followed by six months of monthly sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of occlusal interventions (splints or adjustments) on temporomandibular disorders (TMD), focusing on joint pain, muscle pain, quality of life, discomfort, and recurrence.
results_summary: The study found very uncertain evidence regarding the effectiveness of occlusal splints (FHSS type) for TMD, with potential minor reductions in muscle pain when chewing compared to no treatment, but no clear benefits for other outcomes. The overall evidence was inconclusive due to low certainty and methodological limitations.
population_specificity: Participants diagnosed with temporomandibular disorders (TMD), including myogenous, arthrogenous, or mixed types.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included occlusal splints and adjustments, but exact dosages were not detailed).
study_duration: Ranged from 5 weeks to 84 months, with key results measured between 4.4 weeks and 4 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the characteristics, causes, and interdisciplinary treatment approaches for trigeminal neuralgia, including pain triggered by chewing.
results_summary: The abstract notes that innocuous stimuli like chewing can trigger pain in trigeminal neuralgia patients, but it does not evaluate chewing's efficacy or safety as an intervention. The focus is on diagnosing and treating the condition, with carbamazepine as first-choice therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with trigeminal neuralgia (idiopathic, classic, or secondary).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of High-intensity laser therapy (HILT) on pain intensity, mouth opening, disability, and quality of life in individuals with temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: The study conducted a meta-analysis of RCTs, finding that HILT significantly reduced pain intensity (VAS) and improved mouth opening (mm), disability (JFLS-20), and quality of life (OHIP-14) in TMD patients.
population_specificity: Individuals suffering from temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the salivary proteomic profiles of smokeless tobacco users, non-users, and oral cancer patients to identify potential biomarkers and pathways associated with oral cancer risk.
results_summary: The study found significant overlap in dysregulated proteins between smokeless tobacco users and oral cancer patients, including increased levels of Apolipoprotein A1 (ApoA1) and Pon1, and decreased mitochondrial proteins, suggesting a shift toward an oncogenic state.
population_specificity: 65 participants divided into control (25), smokeless tobacco users (25), and oral cancer patients (15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether anastomosing the transected hypoglossal nerve using the ramus descendens hypoglossi could prevent tongue deviation and dysfunction (including chewing difficulty) in patients undergoing hypoglossal-facial nerve anastomosis (HFA) for severe facial palsy.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly reduced tongue deviation and lower rates of chewing difficulty (1/10 vs 3/10), though this difference was not statistically significant. The tongue disability index (TDI) was significantly lower in the intervention group, indicating improved tongue function.
population_specificity: Adult patients with severe peripheral facial palsy (House-Brackmann grade V or VI) unresponsive to at least 6 months of conservative treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using surface electromyography (sEMG) during swallowing and chewing tasks in pediatric populations, particularly those with cerebral palsy (CP) and dysphagia.
results_summary: The study found that sEMG measurements during swallowing (including chewing) were feasible in children with various diagnoses, including CP and dysphagia. However, some difficulties during sEMG data collection were noted.
population_specificity: Pediatric populations, including children with cerebral palsy (CP) and dysphagia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare masticatory performance in children receiving preformed metal crowns via Hall technique versus conventional technique.
results_summary: Masticatory performance initially decreased post-intervention but returned to baseline levels within 3 months, with no significant discomfort or pain reported in either group.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-10 years requiring restorative/endodontic therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare intra and postoperative complications of frenectomy procedures using a surgical scalpel versus 445 nm and 980 nm diode lasers, focusing on outcomes like pain, bleeding, discomfort in chewing and speaking, and tissue healing.
results_summary: The 445 nm diode laser group showed significantly lower pain, faster tissue healing, and reduced discomfort in chewing and speaking compared to both the 980 nm laser and scalpel groups. Both laser groups outperformed the scalpel group in reducing intraoperative bleeding and improving postoperative outcomes.
population_specificity: 174 patients requiring maxillary labial frenectomy after fixed orthodontic treatment and primary closure of maxillary diastema.
effective_dosage: 445 nm diode laser (1.5 W, continuous-wave), 980 nm diode laser (1.7 W, continuous-wave).
study_duration: Outcomes assessed immediately, at 7 days, and 30 days postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nonpharmacological interventions, including chewing gum, in preventing and treating postoperative ileus (POI) in colorectal surgery patients.
results_summary: Chewing gum was among the interventions that led to quicker return of bowel function, shorter hospital stays, fewer complications, and improved quality of life compared to control groups. The study found these interventions effective in mitigating POI.
population_specificity: Colorectal surgery patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ultrasonic subgingival curettage combined with antibacterial polypeptide periodontal gel in treating moderate to severe chronic periodontitis and its impact on chewing efficiency.
results_summary: Both treatment groups showed significant reductions in occlusal duration, occlusal force balance, and masticatory efficiency standard deviation, with the observation group (receiving polypeptide periodontal gel) demonstrating more pronounced improvements compared to the control group. The authors concluded that the combined treatment effectively reduces inflammation and enhances periodontal health while improving chewing efficiency.
population_specificity: 500 hospitalized patients with moderate to severe chronic periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of chewing gum as a non-pharmacological intervention for preventing postoperative ileus (POI).
results_summary: The study found that chewing gum, as part of enhanced recovery programs, significantly reduced both the frequency and duration of POI without any reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgery (specific surgical specialties not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the shear bond strength and color stability of zirconia and PEEK when used with indirect composite in dental prostheses before and after aging.
results_summary: PEEK showed higher shear bond strength than zirconia both before and after thermocycling, though its strength decreased slightly post-aging. Color stability was better for PEEK compared to zirconia, with both materials showing clinically acceptable ΔE values.
population_specificity: In vitro study using 96 samples of zirconia and PEEK for dental prostheses.
study_duration: Simulated 1 year of clinical use via 10,000 thermocycling cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify how sinonasal malignancies and their treatments impact specific quality-of-life areas, including chewing, over a 5-year period.
results_summary: Maxillary involvement predicted worse chewing outcomes compared to other tumor sites, with a statistically significant negative impact (CI 9.8, 33.2; p < 0.001). Endoscopic resection was associated with better chewing outcomes relative to open or combined surgical approaches.
population_specificity: 273 patients with sinonasal malignancies who underwent definitive treatment with curative intent.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing hard gummy candy could improve masticatory function (lip-closing force, occlusal force, and masticatory performance) in Japanese children aged 6-12 years.
results_summary: Chewing hard gummy candy significantly improved lip-closing and right occlusal forces, with effects persisting for 4 weeks post-training. Masticatory performance also improved during training but deteriorated substantially after cessation.
population_specificity: Japanese children aged 6-12 years (10 boys, 16 girls; mean age 9.3 ± 0.3 years).
effective_dosage: Twice daily chewing of hard gummy candy.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with follow-up assessments at 4 weeks post-completion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare masticatory performance and patient satisfaction between conventional heat-cured acrylic resin and 3D-printed mandibular implant overdentures retained with bar attachment.
results_summary: No significant difference in masticatory performance was found between the two types of overdentures. Patient satisfaction was similar except for aesthetics, which favored conventional overdentures.
population_specificity: Sixteen completely edentulous healthy participants.

study_goal: The researchers were examining potential treatments for trigeminal neuralgia, including the role of chewing as a trigger for pain attacks.
results_summary: The abstract discusses that chewing can trigger painful attacks in trigeminal neuralgia patients but does not evaluate chewing itself as a treatment or intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with trigeminal neuralgia, a rare condition affecting one side of the face.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the mechanical performance of patient-specific prefabricated temporary shell restorations versus laboratory-fabricated CAD/CAM provisional restorations on titanium temporary abutments, with and without thermo-mechanical ageing.
results_summary: The study found that both types of restorations showed 100% survival rates after thermo-mechanical ageing, with no significant differences in fracture load or bending moments between groups. Wear facets were observed but no other complications were reported.
population_specificity: Implants with conical connections, restored with temporary shell or laboratory-fabricated PMMA restorations (central or lateral incisors).
study_duration: Thermo-mechanical ageing involved 120,000 chewing cycles (simulating clinical use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the developmental milestones of chewing and swallowing in infants and identify factors that may interfere with this process.
results_summary: The study outlines the progression from reflexive drinking to voluntary chewing and swallowing in infants, aligning with dietary recommendations. It also highlights that disturbances in motor development, sensory processing, and organic/behavioral issues can disrupt eating skill development, with dysphagia posing serious risks to growth.
population_specificity: Infants in their first year of life, particularly in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of pain, quality of life, and their evolution over four years in patients in remission after oral or oropharyngeal cancer, with a focus on chewing difficulties.
results_summary: The study found that neurosensory disturbances were common, but pain was rare (11.8%). Quality of life improved globally, but persistent issues like dry mouth and chewing difficulties remained unresolved.
population_specificity: 21 patients in remission after oral or oropharyngeal cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to consolidate existing research to provide a comprehensive understanding of the global prevalence of smokeless tobacco (SLT) use among women of reproductive age.
results_summary: The study conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to determine SLT prevalence among women of reproductive age, using observational studies and assessing study quality with the JBI tool. The meta-analysis employed a random-effects model and statistical tools like forest plots.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age
